dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so here's the thing. Everyone's talking about, like, another financial crisis, right? But didn't we fix all that after 2008? I mean, come on, won't it be, uh, another 20, 30 years before we see anything that bad again?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so here's the thing. Everyone's talking about, like, another financial crisis, right? But didn't we fix all that after two thousand eight? I mean, come on, won't it be, uh, another twenty, thirty years before we see anything that bad again?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But wont it be another 20-40 years before the next big financial crisis, leaving plenty of time to get ready? One hopes so, but it is far from certain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, you'd think so, normally. Systemic crises, they're not like your typical recession. They're pretty rare, actually. But, um, we're not exactly in normal times anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, you'd think so, normally. Systemic crises, they're not like your typical recession. They're pretty rare, actually. But, um, we're not exactly in normal times anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The kind of full-blown systemic global financial crisis that erupted a decade ago is not like a typical septennial recession. The much lower frequency of systemic crises reflects two realities... Unfortunately, we dont live in normal times.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not normal? What do you mean 'not normal'? We have, like, new regulations, right? Dodd-Frank and stuff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not normal? What do you mean 'not normal'? We have, like, new regulations, right? Dodd-Frank and stuff?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, we do. And policymakers did put reforms in place. The problem is, crisis management isn't just about, uh, ticking boxes. It depends hugely on the competence of the entire government, not just the central bank.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, we do. And policymakers did put reforms in place. The problem is, crisis management isn't just about, uh, ticking boxes. It depends hugely on the competence of the entire government, not just the central bank.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bad news is that crisis management involves the entire government, not just the monetary authority.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The entire government? So, like, the, uh, the folks in charge now? You mean like the Trump administration? With, like, SEC budget cuts and... Mnuchin?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The entire government? So, like, the, uh, the folks in charge now? You mean like the Trump administration? With, like, S E C budget cuts and... Mnuchin?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Can anyone honestly say that US President Donald Trumps administration has the skill and experience to deal with a major collapse? ... Or perhaps Steven Mnuchin, who produced Hollywood movies prior to becoming US Treasury Secretary, can use insights from his acting role in the 2016 movie Rules Dont Apply.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, exactly. I mean, the Fed, they're generally first-rate. But who else is in the room? The Fed can't do it all, especially with Dodd-Frank restricting their ability to bail out private institutions now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, exactly. I mean, the Fed, they're generally first-rate. But who else is in the room? The Fed can't do it all, especially with Dodd-Frank restricting their ability to bail out private institutions now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell and his team are first-rate, but who will be the other adults in the room if an externally generated financial crisis threatens? ... In fact, the Fed has less room for maneuver than it had in 2008, because the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reforms sharply restricted its ability to bail out private institutions, even if the entire system might otherwise collapse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. So, if it's like a huge cyberattack, or, uh, some totally new kind of problem, not just banks failing... we're kinda stuck?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow. So, if it's like a huge cyberattack, or, uh, some totally new kind of problem, not just banks failing... we're kinda stuck?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But what if the next crisis is completely different, resulting from say, a severe cyberattack, or an unexpectedly rapid rise in global real interest rates, which rocks fragile markets for high-risk debt?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Potentially, yeah. What if the next crisis isn't exactly like 2008? A cyberattack from, say, North Korea? Or, um, a rapid rise in global interest rates? And then you've got a gridlocked Congress, deep divisions... It just makes it harder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Potentially, yeah. What if the next crisis isn't exactly like two thousand eight? A cyberattack from, say, North Korea? Or, um, a rapid rise in global interest rates? And then you've got a gridlocked Congress, deep divisions... It just makes it harder.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But what if the next crisis is completely different, resulting from say, a severe cyberattack, or an unexpectedly rapid rise in global real interest rates, which rocks fragile markets for high-risk debt? ... Will a gridlocked Congress deliver?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, Europe too, right? Like, with Brexit and everything. They're not exactly, like, stable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, uh, Europe too, right? Like, with Brexit and everything. They're not exactly, like, stable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe has issues that are similar, or worse. With populism fueling deep distrust and divisions, financial resilience is almost certainly far lower than it was a decade ago. Just look at the United Kingdom, the other major global financial center, where the political elite have taken the country to the edge of the Brexit cliff.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Populism, deep distrust, divisions over things like eurozone burden sharing. Their financial resilience is probably lower than it was a decade ago, uh, unfortunately.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Populism, deep distrust, divisions over things like eurozone burden sharing. Their financial resilience is probably lower than it was a decade ago, uh, unfortunately.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With populism fueling deep distrust and divisions, financial resilience is almost certainly far lower than it was a decade ago. ... Meanwhile, across the English Channel, deep division over eurozone burden sharing will make it difficult to implement a cogent policy for dealing with a bout of severe stress.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But still, even with all that, um, you really think it could come sooner than twenty years? I thought these things, like, happen once a generation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But still, even with all that, um, you really think it could come sooner than twenty years? I thought these things, like, happen once a generation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the hope, that there's plenty of time. But it's far from certain. The biggest issue is that while regulations might have contained risks in traditional banks, a lot of the risk has, uh, just migrated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the hope, that there's plenty of time. But it's far from certain. The biggest issue is that while regulations might have contained risks in traditional banks, a lot of the risk has, uh, just migrated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even if regulations have been successful in containing risks to banks, it is likely that major sources of risk have simply migrated to the less regulated shadow financial system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Migrated where? Like, to, uh, the metaverse or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Migrated where? Like, to, uh, the metaverse or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not quite the metaverse, more like the less regulated 'shadow financial system' and decentralized finance, or DeFi. It's, um, huge. And it's growing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not quite the metaverse, more like the less regulated 'shadow financial system' and decentralized finance, or DeFi. It's, um, huge. And it's growing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: it is likely that major sources of risk have simply migrated to the less regulated shadow financial system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Global debt is pushing two hundred trillion dollars. So, yeah, the financial system keeps expanding. And those assets that seem liquid in normal times? They can become, uh, highly illiquid when things go south.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Global debt is pushing two hundred trillion dollars. So, yeah, the financial system keeps expanding. And those assets that seem liquid in normal times? They can become, uh, highly illiquid when things go south.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What we know for sure is that the global financial system continues to expand, with global debt now pushing $200 trillion. ... Unfortunately, assets that are liquid in normal times often turn out to be highly illiquid in a crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, we're not ready. And it's, like, a ticking time bomb because of politics and, uh, new kinds of financial stuff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, we're not ready. And it's, like, a ticking time bomb because of politics and, uh, new kinds of financial stuff?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. An inexorably growing financial system, combined with a pretty toxic political environment, means the next major crisis, uh, could definitely come sooner than many people think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. An inexorably growing financial system, combined with a pretty toxic political environment, means the next major crisis, uh, could definitely come sooner than many people think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, an inexorably growing financial system, combined with an increasingly toxic political environment, means that the next major financial crisis may come sooner than you think.
